abstract.p: Russian oil company Sidanco says it will proceed with plan to regain important production unit, despite opposition from rival company that threatens to unravel deal; Sidanco, which is 10 percent owned by BP Amoco, lost its subsidiary last year when Tyuman Oil pushed it into bankruptcy; companies agreed to salvage BP Amoco's investment in Sidanco last December by giving Tyumen stake in company in exchange for returning assets; Tyumen says it will not participate if Sidanco gives Tyumen new shares instead of existing shares (S)

block.p: A Russian oil company said it would proceed with a plan to regain an important production unit, despite opposition from a rival company that threatens to unravel the deal. Sidanco, which is 10 percent owned by BP Amoco, lost its subsidiary last year when Tyumen Oil pushed it into bankruptcy. The companies agreed to salvage BP Amoco's investment in Sidanco last December by giving Tyumen a stake in the company in exchange for returning assets. But Tyumen now says it will not participate if Sidanco gives Tyumen new shares instead of existing shares.

The companies agreed to salvage BP Amoco's investment in Sidanco last December by giving Tyumen a stake in the company in exchange for returning assets. But Tyumen now says it will not participate if Sidanco gives Tyumen new shares instead of existing shares.
